body_text.text: Let R overall denote the number of new infections caused by each case, averaged over all cases. Let µ be the average size of transmission chain (i.e. all cases that are linked to an index case). Then on average, µ cases cause µ − 1 infections (because the index case is caused by any case in the chain). Therefore [Harris, 2002 , Lange, 2010 ,
body_text.section: reproduction numbers of index and secondary cases

body_text.text: Meanwhile the index case is expected to generate R i cases in the first generation of secondary cases. These cases are expected to generate R i · R s cases in the second generation. These in turn produce R i · R 2 s cases in the third generation and so forth. Therefore,

body_text.text: portion of asymptomatic index cases that are unobserved Here we consider adjustments to the observed value of R i and R overall for the possibility that asymptomatic, unobserved index cases were not incorporated into the initial data analysis. We assume that the proportion of symptomatic, observed index cases is ρ i,c and that the proportion of unobserved index cases is 1 − ρ i,c . Let R o i and R o overall and µ o represent the values of R i ,R s and the average chain size based solely on observed data. Let R a i and R a overall and µ a represents the corresponding values, once adjusted for unobserved asymptomatic index cases.
